docs.lead_paragraph: With some of its oldest buildings in need of repair, Cornell University has drawn up plans to spend almost $100 million to renovate, repair and update them. The plans are complete, the money is in place and local contractors are ready to go to work. But the Mayor of Ithaca, himself a former engineering professor at Cornell, has blocked construction, saying the university must first start paying more of its fair share for city services. He wants $2.5 million a year from Cornell, more than eight times its current contribution and roughly 10 percent of the city's budget.

headline.main: Ithaca's Mayor Blocks Cornell Construction Projects

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Medical Association, which last month achieved a stunning victory in the House, discovered today that it has far less influence in the Senate. As the Senate barreled toward a likely showdown vote on Thursday on legislation to overhaul the nation's civil litigation system, it firmly rejected an amendment long sought by the A.M.A. The amendment would have limited the compensation patients can receive for "pain and suffering" in medical malpractice suits.

headline.main: Senate Rejects Limit on Compensation for Pain

docs.lead_paragraph: House Speaker Newt Gingrich's pledge to insulate Medicare from deficit reduction cuts and save it from bankruptcy may please the elderly. But the plan has no chance of working and, if really carried out, would make the Republicans' deficit reduction program harsh beyond bearing. The Republican leadership had planned to cut Medicare by at least $250 billion as part of its proposal to balance the budget by the year 2002. But after lobbyists for the elderly registered alarm, Mr. Gingrich and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, sent up a clever smokescreen. They promised to remove Medicare from deficit reduction demands -- and to use any savings achieved by restructuring Medicare solely to save the Medicare trust fund itself from looming bankruptcy.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHIPLASH, a common neck injury that affects 120,000 Americans a year, usually after automobile accidents, is little understood and often ineffectively treated, a new study has found. An international team of experts who reviewed more than 10,000 scientific articles published in the last 15 years found little scientifically rigorous evidence to justify most existing therapies, and also found that most are prescribed by doctors who are poorly trained in caring for whiplash patients.

headline.main: Whiplash Treatments Found to Be Ineffective

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House today spurned Speaker Newt Gingrich's invitation to propose ways of restructuring Medicare and said the Republicans in Congress must first specify how they intend to reconcile their promises to balance the budget and cut taxes. President Clinton's chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, said the Administration was not interested in any plan to shore up the Medicare trust fund unless it also made comprehensive improvements in the nation's health care system and provided coverage to some of the 41 million Americans who now have no health insurance.

headline.main: White House Spurns Request By Gingrich About Medicare

docs.snippet: The White House today spurned Speaker Newt Gingrich's invitation to propose ways of restructuring Medicare and said the Republicans in Congress must first specify how they intend to reconcile their promises to balance the budget and cut taxes.  ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Speaker Newt Gingrich tonight escalated his attack on the Clinton Administration over its handling of the Medicare issue, accusing it of "totally unacceptable behavior" and asserting that the President and his aides were engaged in "a demagogic campaign" aimed at scaring the elderly. Mr. Gingrich's remarks, made to the conservative political action committee Gopac, represented his latest effort effort to counter Administration contentions that the Republican Party is planning a raid on the insurance program for the elderly to pay for its political promises. The Republicans are expected to seek deep cuts in projected spending on Medicare as part of their drive to balance the budget by 2002 while providing billions of dollars in tax cuts.

headline.main: Clinton Attacked by Gingrich Over Making Cuts in Medicare

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans and Democrats are at war again over Medicare. The back and forth of the last few days has largely been political positioning. But it shrouds some serious substantive decisions facing the President and Congress that could significantly affect the medical insurance available to 40 million elderly and disabled Americans.

headline.main: In the War of Politics, Medicare Spending Has Become the Latest Battlefield

docs.snippet: Republicans and Democrats are at war again over Medicare.   The back and forth of the last few days has largely been political positioning. But it shrouds some serious substantive decisions facing the President and Congress that could significantly...

docs.lead_paragraph: As delegates arrived here for a White House conference on aging, Republican leaders of Congress said today that they would defer proposals to restructure Medicare for at least several months so the politically explosive question of health care for the elderly would not become entangled in Congressional efforts to slash the Federal budget deficit. Administration officials said that President Clinton would use the conference this week as a platform from which to portray himself as a defender of Medicare against budget-cutting Republicans in Congress.

headline.main: G.O.P. Vows to Isolate Medicare From Budget-Cutting Debate
